channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Held in Israeli Prison Dies in Shootout
item.description: The death of Samuel Sheinbein, who fled to Israel after a murder in Maryland, brought a dramatic conclusion to a painful episode that had strained American-Israeli relations.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Strong Finish Gives Russia Most Medals
item.description: As Nicklas Backstrom of Sweden was barred from the hockey title game after failing a drug test, bobsledder Alexander Zubkov and cross-country racer Alexander Legkov helped the host nation top the final medals standings.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Alexander Zubkov of Russia led the four-man bobsled team to a gold medal finish.

item.title: The Lede: Live Video and Social Media Updates From Ukraine
item.description: Video and social media updates on a day of upheaval in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Yulia Tymoshenko, Ukraine's former prime minister and a leader of the 2004 revolution, seemed to be fighting back tears as she addressed protesters in Kiev on Saturday night.

item.title: Taliban Raid Afghan Army Base, Killing Soldiers in Their Sleep
item.description: The attack, which left 21 soldiers dead, came as the insurgents acknowledged they had suspended talks with the Americans aimed at a prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: By NIAMATULLAH KARYAB and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Old Railroad Stirs Memories of a Pre-Industrial China
item.description: A reporter visits his family’s ancestral home in Guangdong Province, where his father had taken the old Xinning Railway in 1936 with his family, Hong Kongers who were going into the lush countryside to build a new family home.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Taliban Attack Afghan Army Base, Killing Soldiers in Their Sleep
item.description: The attack, which left 21 soldiers dead, came as the insurgents acknowledged they had suspended talks with the Americans aimed at a prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Canada 3, Sweden 0: Stingy Defense Adds to Canada’s Gold Pile
item.description: Sidney Crosby scored his first goal of the tournament as the Canadian men won their second consecutive Olympic title. Canada defended its title in men’s hockey with a 3-0 victory over Sweden on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By KEN BELSON
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sidney Crosby celebrated his goal in the second period that seemed to deflate Sweden.

item.title: Ukraine Parliament Moves Swiftly to Dismantle President’s Government
item.description: Lawmakers fired top cabinet members in President Viktor F. Yanukovych’s government and restored state ownership of the presidential palace.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Viktor Yanukovych denounced a “coup” on TV.

item.title: Deadly Violence Strikes Antigovernment Rallies in Thailand
item.description: Three people were killed, including two children, and more than 50 injured at protests over the weekend as the country’s protracted power struggle further devolved.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Archrival Is Freed as Ukraine Leader Flees
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych fled Kiev, denouncing what he called a violent coup, as his nemesis, former Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, was released from prison and Parliament found him unable to fulfill his duties.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Presidential Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Viktor Yanukovych denounced a “coup” on TV.

item.title: A Forensic Approach to a Sidewalk Nuisance
item.description: Although some officials were not amused, many Neapolitans welcomed a new campaign to track down owners who do not pick up after their dogs by using the animals’ DNA samples.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A dog named Daisy and its owner in Naples, Italy, which has started a DNA database to find owners who do not pick up after pets.

item.title: Kerry Says Venezuela Crackdown Is ‘Unacceptable’
item.description: As the demonstrations continued to grow, Secretary of State John Kerry strengthened his criticism of the Venezuelan government’s response to the protesters.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Lviv, in Western Ukraine, Mourns One of Its Own Killed in Kiev
item.description: A university lecturer who was shot to death had made several trips east to the capital to take part in antigovernment protests, a friend said.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: In Japan’s Drill With the U.S., a Message for Beijing
item.description: American military officials insisted an annual exercise, called Iron Fist, had nothing to do with a dispute over islands, but this year, the Japanese team came packing.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: An officer watched as Marines and Japanese soldiers were transported during an annual joint exercise called Iron Fist in Camp Pendleton, Calif.

item.title: Asylum Fraud in Chinatown: An Industry of Lies
item.description: More Chinese immigrants seek asylum than any other immigrant group in the country, and most of them apply from New York, where federal officials regard the applicant pool with suspicion.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE, JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and JEFFREY E. SINGER
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents outside 2 East Broadway in Chinatown, an office raided in December 2012 during an investigation into immigration fraud. More than 30 people have been charged.

item.title: El Chapo, Most-Wanted Drug Lord, Is Captured in Mexico
item.description: Mexican marines and the police, aided by information from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the United States Marshals Service, took him into custody without firing a shot.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and GINGER THOMPSON
item.media:description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was escorted to a helicopter in handcuffs in Mexico City on Saturday.

item.title: Border’s New Sentinels Are Robots, Penetrating Deepest Drug Routes
item.description: Robots, valued for their speed and maneuverability, can serve as the first eyes on drug-smuggling tunnels that traverse the United States border with Mexico.
item.dc:creator: By FERNANDA SANTOS

item.title: After Farmers Commit Suicide, Debts Fall on Families in India
item.description: India’s small farmers, once the country’s economic backbone and most reliable vote bank, are increasingly being left behind.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: South Korea Puts Anger Aside After Olympic Skating Disappointment
item.description: When the figure skater Kim Yu-na was dethroned in Sochi by a Russian teenager, her country, which has long tied sports achievements to self-worth, reacted with anger.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Kim Yu-na of South Korea, who won an Olympic gold medal in figure skating in 2010, had to settle for silver in 2014 behind a Russian teenager.

item.title: Behind Gates, Bizarre Vision of Opulence
item.description: After the departure of President Viktor F. Yanukovych, his sprawling compound was opened, revealing a golf course, a private zoo, classic cars and a restaurant in the form of a pirate ship, among other things.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: U.N. Orders Both Sides in Syria to Allow Humanitarian Aid
item.description: The resolution, unanimously adopted by the Security Council, calls on the Syrian government to allow relief agencies to enter the country, and strongly condemns terror attacks, plainly referring to some of the rebels.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Lede: Venezuela Battles Media, Social and Otherwise, to Restrict Protest Coverage
item.description: Tensions escalated further in Venezuela on Friday, as protesters turned out for a tenth day of demonstrations and the government continued to clamp down on coverage of the unrest in the broadcast media and online.
item.dc:creator: By NATALIE KITROEFF

item.title: Gunmen Wound at Least 35 at Rally in Thailand
item.description: Assailants in a pickup truck attacked the antigovernment rally held by the People’s Democratic Reform Committee in the province of Trat, about 180 miles east of Bangkok.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Opinion: Mumbai’s Empty Parlor Games
item.description: Socializing with sycophants and hypocrites.
item.dc:creator: By SIDDHARTH DHANVANT SHANGHVI
item.media:description: The Indian journalist Tarun Tejpal before boarding a flight from New Delhi to Goa, in November. He was to face charges that he sexually assaulted a junior colleague.

item.title: In a First for Spain, a Woman Is Convicted of Inciting Terror Over Twitter
item.description: The case is one of a recent handful that have pushed social media into courtrooms worldwide and raised issues of the limits of speech on the Internet.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Alba González Camacho, 21, posted messages calling for politicians to be killed.
